label: TRAINING
data_answer: Wikipedia is known to be a trusted source of information, but who is to say that every entry on wikipedia contains solid facts. In source #4, Shane Fitzgerald, an Irish student from Dublin University, conducted a test to see how fast blogs and entries were spread. He conducted his research by posting a poetic, but false, quote on Wikipedia. The qoute was supposably by Maurice Jarre and was posted on the French composer's page hours after his death on March 28. This quote flew straight into dozens of U.S. blogs and newspaper Web sites in Britain, Australia and India. Administrators at wikipedia quickly caught the quote's lack of attribution and removed it from the site. A full month went by and nobody nodiced that the editorial was false. Because of the test results, Fitzgerald was one hundred percent convinced that if he hadn't come foward, the false quote would have gone down in history as something Maurice Jarre said, instead of something he made up. Source #5 also demonstrates that misinformation posted on Wikipedia can spread quickly. In Middlebury College, Vermont, half a dozen students in Neil Waters' Japanese history class asserted on exams that the Jesuits supported the Shimaba Rebellion in 17th-Century Japan. Waters knew something was wrong. According to his knowledge the Jesuits were in "no position to aid a revolution, the few of them in Japan were hiding." Where was this misleading information comming from? Waters and other professors in the history department had begun noticing that about a year ago, students were citing wikipedia as a source in their papers. More misinformation spread and certain errors showed up on last semesters test. Those errors came from the information of wikipedia. Both these sources show how fast and easily misleading information can spread.

This phony quote was used in blogs and newspapers at the start and finish of their obituaries. This demonstrates unreliable monitoring by Wikipedia and that false information posted on Wikipedia does spread rapidly.

data_answer: The ability to add one's personal input about a certain topic on Wikipedia is a growing problem for the rest of the users who rely on this website for their own purposes. For example, Source 2 describes how, even when it first began to indulge in its promising prominence, Wikipedia had to face a serious problem- vandalism. Many people are able to edit any page they want on Wikipedia but the "user-generated encyclopedia" has not changed its settings from allowing anybody to modify pages to allowing only a certain group of people who can be depended on providing accurate information; this allows the spread of misinformation to increasingly grow. Even if the creator of this online encyclopedia decides to ban the freedom of adding information onto its pages whenever someone chooses to do so, most of the information that people will get, in order to undeniably modify the Wikipedia pages that have been plagued by the vandalism of misinformation, are from the internet, where the infinite sources that claim to be truthful are all but just exaggerated stories or lies. In addition, Source 4 explains how one Irish student managed to fool whole nations all over the world. By posting a made up quote on Wikipedia, much less the internet, it was only a matter of time until people from different parts of the world were bound to see it. With the incredibly fast way technology works today, anything that is posted on the internet can be transmitted in seconds. These demonstrations of adding misinformation that is irrelevant to a topic or article on an international website can spread quickly like wildfire on a dry, humid day.

data_answer: There are many reasons as to why this might happen. The first reason is not double checking. In the age of the internet, you can always double and triple check something like a fact or a quote. Careless writers and journalist may are subject to the possiblity of misinformation when they only check one source. An example of this is form: Irish student hoaxes world's media with fake quote (source 4), " They used fabricated materical, Fitzgerald said, even thoguh administrators at the free online encyclopedia quickly caught the quote's lack of attrib.ution removed it, but not quickly enough to keep some journalists fom cutting and pasting it first." Another example is a lot of people use the information and feel comfortable that others are using it too, so it must be right. however that is a theory that can be proven wrong. This is shown in: Wikipedia on an academic hit list (source 5), "He firgured out the problem soon enough. the obscure, though incorrect, information was from Wikipedia, the collaborative online encyclopedia, and the students had picked it up cramming for his exam." Those are the ways that misinformation can spread quickly.

data_answer: Misinformation on Wikipedia can spread quickly, as seen in Sources 4 and 5. In Source 4, Shane Fitzgerald conducted an experiment to see how "media was upholding accuracy". It is seen that journalists had quickly taken the quote to use for information without first making sure that it was reliable. This misinformation was spread quickly because journalists, those who are supposed to check for reliable information and give it to the public, did not do their job properly. In Source 5, high school students were shown to have relied heavily on Wikipedia as a citable source of information, and since teachers had let them use such information before, students kept on using unreliable information in their work. Thus, Wikipedia's large database of information appealed to students and gained popularity among them. This misinformation was spread due to lack of care by both teachers and students alike. Therefore, misinformation on Wikipedia is spread quickly due to lack of attention and care by both amateurs, teachers, and experts alike.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Misinformation posted on Wikipedia can spread quickly, as proven by Sources #4 and #5. In Source #4, Shane Fitzgerald, a Dublin University student, "posted a poetic but phony quote on Wikipedia" to test how our "globalized, increasingly Internet-dependent media was upholding accuracy and accountability in an age of instant news." Although the quote Fitzgerald posted on the site was fake, Wikipedia users and administrators themselves were blind to the quote's infidelity. After a month of silence, Fitzgerald decided that if he had not told the truth about his made-up quote, it "would have gone down in history as something Maurice Jarre said, instead of something I made up." This proves that misinformation can not only be considered credible in daily life, but also in widespread, international history, as suggested by Fitzgerald. In his article from The Taipei Times entitled "Wikipedia on an academic hit list," Noam Cohen affirms that misinformation can spread quickly. Cohen opens his piece by connecting the unreliabilty of Wikipedia to real life situations. In his Japanese history class, Neil Waters found that most of his students stated the same untrue statement in their exams. After investigation, Waters found that the "obscure, though incorrect, information was from Wikipedia, the collaborative online encyclopedia, and the students had picked it up cramming for his exam." Although Wikipedia is a great source for quick, general information, its unreliability cannot be overlooked, especially in the case of a last-minute "cramming session." The incorrect statement Waters identified in most of his students' exams came from the exact same place, showing that many students use Wikipedia as a resource, and consequently, any untrue information presented in Wikipedia can be directly spread to its users, and even indirectly spread to others. Therefore, the incidence in Waters' history class confirms that misinformation can spread quickly.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: With so many users, information found on Wikipedia is easily found and spread, whether it's correct or incorrect. For example, in source 4, when discussing the fraudulent quote posted by an Irish student, the author paraphrases Fitzgerald's words and reports that "[Journalists] used the fabricated material...even though adminitrators at the free online encyclopedia quickly caught the quote's lack of attribution and removed it, but not quickly enough to keep some journalists from cutting and pasting it first." In an article by Noam Cohen, it is revealed that half a dozen students got the wrong answer on a test after using Wikipedia, where "the students had picked [the incorrect information] up cramming for [teacher Neil Waters] exam." When information is as easily accessible as a Wikipedia article, it is destined to be subjected to widespread use.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: In this Information Age, the Internet is often called as the Sea of Information and has enormous influence on people's daily lives. People around the world read everything from new articles to published research papers on their phones or tablet PCs at every second. Therefore even a tiny piece of misinformation is spread around the world in an instant. To test how the media would take in misinformation posted on a Wikipedia article, Shane Fitzgerald from Dublin University placed a false quote on a Wikipedia article on Maurice Jarre. What he found was astounding. Instanly, the media, especially journalists and the news, began to use the quote on their reports. [Source #4]. The misinformation was unnoticed by some 40 million users until Fitzgerald told the media the truth. The reason this event occured is mainly because of the tendency of people to believe what is written on the Internet. They believe that Wikipedia articles have been checked by the experts before they are posted online. Second reason the misinformation can spread so quickly is that there are just so many people who use the information posted on Wikipedia. With more than 38 million users for articles in English when the articles are written in more than 270 languages [Source #2], even if the quote was online for just a few seconds, dozens or even hundreds of people would have seen that quote in that article.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Wikipedia is a tool that is used for the access of information, but being a user edited site, it can be liable to misinformation. After the death of a famous poet, many people flocked to Wikipedia to find out more about him. Seeing an opportunity in this, a fake quote was placed in the poet's entry and it, "flew straight on to dozens of blogs and newspaper Web sites in Britain, Australia and India." (4) An important event may cause an extreme spread of misinformation if it is not caught on time by Wikipedia's editors. Situations may also occur where people need to know something in order to prepare, for example students preparing for an exam. At Middlebury College, many students, "asserted on exams that the Jesuits supported the Shimabara Rebellion in 17th-century Japan." This need for information also can contribute to the spread of misinformation.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: In source 4, the narrator explains the spreading of false attribution,"even though administrators at the free online encyclpedia quickly caught the quote's lack of attribution and removed it, but not quickly enough to keep some jouarnalists from cutting and pasting it first"(4). One of the reasons that misinformation spread without being stopped is that there are simply more journalists spreading the word compared to the editors who are getting rid of it.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: In the artricle "A Brief History of Wikipedia," Fletcher states that there were some prolems when it came to Wiki. Such as vandalism and overseeing what should and shouldn't go on the site. The accuracy of Wiki was also a problem; the Wiki resource has similar accuracy and depth to the professionally edited database. Because of these problems, misinformation can easily spread quickly and people could easily use wrong information without knowledge of it being false. In source 4, when Shane Fitzgerald posted a poetic, but fake quote on Wikipedia that French composer Maurice Jarre "supossedly" said, journalism blew it up without even knowing if the source was real or not. Fitzgerald did this as an experiment to see how fast false news could spread through the internet. His experiment worked seeming how most blogs and newspapers were using his phony quote. This clearly shows that when using Wikipedia it's almost taking a fifty/fifty chance that you could be using false information. Misinformation can spread like wildfire on the internet and this is a clear example of it.

The example in Source 4 where a college student posted a fake qoute and "a full month went by and nobody noticed the editorial fruad" illustrates people's unwavering belief that all Wikipedia information is accurate. Some people no longer question the credibility of a source, and instead absentmindedly copy down what is shown. In thinking that the information given is the truth, many can learn and relay incorrect concepts. Wikipedia is "created by users, not traditional 'experts' "(Source 3). Although the site tries to be as accurate as possible, -which gains the faith of its users- the belief that everything on the site is factual makes misinformation spread rapidly.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Misinformation posted on Wikipedia can occur and spread quickly because anyone can edit it, and everyone can look at it. Source #4 is an article that tells about Shane Fitzgerald, a student at Dublin university who posted a fake quote on Wikipedia. He did it to test how well the increasingly Internet dependant media was upholding accuracy and accountability of information. Journalists and newspapers used this information, and a month went by and nobody noticed. It was not until Fitzgerald told these media outlets that the corrections began. The problem is, most consumers of these media sources do not check back for corrections. Also, many of them will tell their friends about what they heard or read. There's no doubt that there are many people who are misinformed because of Wikipedia. In Source #5, several students in a history class had the same wrong answer on an exam. It turned out that they had gotten this information from Wikipedia while studying for the test. Wikipedia has millions of users and articles. Anyone can post misinformation that millions of people will read, and in most cases, believe.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Wikipedia has been found to hold false information in its lifetime. For example, students at Middlebury College used false info on Wikipedia for Neil Waters' Japanese history class as they "had picked it up cramming for his exam." (#5) Students who had studied this topic used false information on Wikipedia to help for their exam which the students did not study for effectively. Due to this, the history branch banned Wikipedia for being cited in essays/classwork. Another example would be the false quote spread by Shane Fitzgerald to test "how the media would handle it." (#4) Journalists from the United States and Great Britain were soon found to be using the false quote in their articles with no citation whatsoever. Sites like the Guardian quickly apologized to the public and Fitzgerald, while others instead quickly scorned him for writing false information. Thus, Wikipedia can hold misinformation that could spread very quickly to anyone wanting to read its articles.

data_answer: In source #4, a student from Dublin university was conducting an experiment on false information on Wikipedia; Shane Fitzgerald had posted a false quote that supposedly came from the famous conductor Maurice Jarre, on Wikipedia, testing the media's accuracy on information and accountability on their stories. A few hours after Jarre's death, Shane had posted the quote on Wikipedia and had instantly been put on dozens of U.S. blogs and newspaper Web sites in Britain, Australia and India. This showed that the media doesn't do much research at all, and use any information they can find without tracking it's source. In source #5, Neil Waters, a professor from Middlebury College, Vermont, had realized that his students are being given false information when he read the students exams. Waters had realized that the students have been getting their information from Wikipedia, and this is because they had decided to get it from the website because they had been "cramming," or studying hard for his exam. Wikipedia articles are made by volunteers, and some of these volunteers are either trying to screw people over, or just aren't educated in the article they are writing. Volunteer's should be tested before being able to write articles on Wikipedia, otherwise, people will start distrusting the site and wouldn't come back to it, resulting in Wikipedia losing viewers and users, and the makers of it losing money.

Fitzgerald's test shows how many different journalists easily copied and pasted his false quote to write and spread their own articles on Jarre's mysterious new quote. Also, in "Wikipedia on an Academic Hit List" written by Noam Cohen shows how quickly more than half a dozen students in Neil Waters' Japanese history class accessed an article to cram for an exam. Wikipedia is often used as a quick go-to for students who are trying to cram for essays and finals exams such as students in Waters' class and probably many students across America. data_answer: While many individuals worldwide use Wikipedia, misinformation, through the medium of Wikipedia, is becoming an increasingly common trend. It is extremely simple to look up a subject on Wikipedia and to write up on the subject for a class or for some other means. While it is unlikely that most information on Wikipedia is fabricated, simply editing in false information isn't difficult. In the article, "Irish Student Hoaxes World's Media with Fake Quote", by Shawn Pogatchnik of the Seattle Times. Pogatchnik reports of the social experiment that Irish student Shane Fitzgerald conducted. He made up an uncited quote that was attributed to the late Maurice Jarre. Even though the quote was uncited, dozens of blogs and newspapers worldwide had referenced this quote in their obituary articles of Jarre. A month had passed and the fabrication had not been spotted until Fitzgerald alerted the media sources. Some sources had still misattributed the quote to Jarre several weeks after Fitzgerald alerted the public. The sheer simplicity of taking a quote from a concise and popular well of information, even though the well is user-submitted and the quote had no citations of its sources proved to be too tempting for many journalists and showed the decreasing interest of firsthand sources of a subject. Another example of misinformation spread by means of Wikipedia can be seen in Noam Cohen's article in the Taipei Times, "Wikipedia on an Academic Hit List." Neil Waters of Middlebury College, Vermont had seen several of his students written on exams using information that was completely incorrect. Upon further investigation, Waters discovered that Wikipedia was the source of misinformation, several of his students had used Wikipedia as a last minute cram option for their exams. As Waters had seen, convenience of sources is a reason how misinformation can be spread. It's extremely simple to apply information from Wikipedia which was found as one of the first results of an internet search, instead of looking through several pages for a source specializing in the subject. Not questioning articles of accuracy because of convenience is another reason why misinformation can easily be spread.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Source 4 and 5 illustrate how misinformation can spread quickly; obviously this happens because millions of people view articles daily but as illustrated by source 5, mistakes are quickly removed. The blame does not fall on wikipedia for spreading misinformation however; the blame should be laid on the lazy students, educators, journalists and regular people who do not check the source qoutation's at the bottom of every wikipedia page.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: According to Source #4, a Dublin university student, Shane Fitzgerald, was able to post a "poetic but phony quote on Wikipedia". His fake quote was quickly published on U.S. blogs and newspaper Web sites in Britain, Australia, and India. The fake quote he posted was quickly spread and no one bothered to check the accuracy of it. Source #5 shows how students from a Japanese history class at Middlebury College put their faith in Wikipedia, and were actually being fed the wrong information. Even though the information on Wikipedia was false, the students still used it. Why? Simply because they didn't know any better and they put their trust into Wikipedia. Because of this, the students began to pass around the wrong information and came up with many errors on their exams.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Because of Wikipedia's enormous volume, easy to access capability, and completely free access nature, it is easy to see why millions of people around the world use it as a source of information on various different subjects. However, Wikipedia's user-edited nature also has a problem, which is that because anyone can alter information on it, flase information can be planted or missed that leads people to false conclusions. Source #4 describes this briliantly because in that source, a student named Shane Fitzgerald intentionally posted false knowledge in order to test how the media responed and if they would factcheck it. When several blogs and media outlets started using the quote as fact, Shane stepped in and informed these outlests that he had made up the quote as an experiment. Even though the false information was brought down quickly, people had already quoted it and displayed it as fact, showing that even though the false material may be found and removed, if it is placed at a key moment in time, it can still reach millions as fact before it is resolved. This effect is evident in source #5 as well where Neil Water's Japanese history class asserted that "the Jesuits supported the Shimabara Rebellion in 17th-century Japan" (Source #5) which was impossible because the Jesuits were few in number and those that existed were in hiding. In this case, the students used Wikipedian information as fact and didn't bother to corroborate their findings from Wikipedia with other sources in the world. Because of the misinformation, six students believed it and tried to pass it off as truth to their teacher in an essay. Both of these sources show that while Wikipedia has enormous stores of knowledge and a lot of people willing to expose and correct mistakes, it can't all be checked all at once and a smartly placed bit of misinformation can go down as truth to millions at a moments notice.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Wikipedia has 3 million articles in the english language, and contains more than 13 million articles in 271 different languages. (source #2) This allows people all over the globe to access the same information. Consequently, the misinformation can spread everywhere rapidly. An Irish student intentionally posted a false quote on a recently dead actress, Maurice Jarre, to see how fast the misinformation spread in the media. His results were that many publications used his quote without checking if it was false or not. (Source #4) Because people do not check the information they get off of Wikipedia, the misinformation in it spreads very quickly, even if Wikipedia takes it down after finding the fault.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Because Wikipedia is an entirely public platform, the spread and use of misinformation is highly likely. In Source #5, a teacher expresses his outrage after dozens of student papers contain false historical information. The teacher harangued Wikipedia for allowing false information to posted on its site, and took furthur action to make sure students would no longer be able to cite Wikipedia in their papers. There are too factors that played into this situation: one is that Wikipedia articles are written by public users not actual experts on the topics, and two is the fact that students are increasingly using the internet for the majority of their research needs. Because most of the site's articles are writing by everyday Joes, the risk for error is about 3.86 mistakes per article (Source # 2). The increase in student use of the internet also caused many of them to cite the source incorrectly.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Misinformation can happen due to promising pieces of information and a pressure to use it. One exmaple can be seen from a quote supposedly from the dying lips of Maurice Jarre posted onto Wikipedia. While many journalists were quick to take in the information as accurate, it turns out that the "poetic but phony quote" was created as an experiment to see how people would take it. The event at Middlebury College in Vermont is another example that also shows that promising information and pressure is a factor in how misinformation can be spread quickly. Under the stress of exams, many of Neil Waters' students turned to Wkipedia for help but found and used "obscure , though incorrect, information"(Cohen).

label: TRAINING
data_answer: To begin with, when false information is entered "administrators at the free online encyclopedia quickly [catch] the [article's] lack of attribution and [remove] it, but not quickly enough to keep some journalists from cutting and pasting it first" (4). This implies that if someone ends up making a mistake on an article, then the chances are that many people would see and record it before the admins can evaluate it. The article also states that "journalists would descend on [the] information without double-checking it" (4). This shows that many journalists make the mistake of shallowly evaluating credbility because they mostly care about spreading news, not checking it.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: After the death of Maurice Jarre, Fitzgerald posted a made-up quote on Wikipedia on Jarre's page. "Administrators at the free online encyclopedia quickly caught the quote's lack of attribution and removed it, but not quickly enough to keep some journalists from cutting and pasting it first" (#4). Many newspapers ended up containing this quote. In Middlebury College, "half a dozen students in Neil Waters' Japanese history class"(#5) had false statements on their exams. The professor found out that the students got the false information from Wikipedia and it was only "a year ago that students [started] citing Wikipedia as a source in their papers" (#5).

data_answer: Misinformation posted on Wikipedia can spread rapidly because so many people use this site for research or reports or even for newspaper obituaries. The reason this misinformation spreads so quickly is because "...once anything becomes printed enough times in the media without challenge, it becomes fact." (Source 4) When one person copies the information from Wikipedia to their own site, someone else can see it on the site and assume it's more credible, so then they use it in their research and it starts to spread globally because it was stated in more than one source, making it "true". Another factor to the quickly spreading misinformation is that many students, not only in middle schools and high schools, but also colleges are using Wikipedia and trusting it as a valid and correct source. "The obscure, though incorrect, information was from Wikipedia, the collaborative online encyclopedia, and the students had picked it up cramming for an exam." (Source 5) This shows that anyone anywhere in the world can find incorrect information and use it for anything they want, causing it to spread all over the place.

data_answer: Misinformation on Wikipedia can be spread quickly among users on the computer mainly due to the fact that several people use this site everyday. In source#4 "Irish student hoaxes worl'd media with a fake quote" by Shawn Pogatchnik, explains a situation of misinformation that was posted on Wikipedia. Pogatchnik wrote "When Dublin university student Shane Fitzgerald posted a poetic but phony quote on Wikipedia, he said he was testing how our globalized, increasingly Internet-dependent media was upholding accuracy and accountability in an age of instant news... The sociology major's made-up quote flew straight on to dozens of U.S. blogs and newspaper Web sites in Britain, Australia, and India." In this article it shows how fast the "phony" quote spreaded around the world. Also in Source #5 Noam Cohen writes about how students had used Wikipedia for "cramming" for an exam lead them to false information. When the teacher put forth the time to figure out how the students were all getting the same false information, he was lead to Wikipedia and set a new rule, " that Wikipedia could not be cited in papers or exams, and that studen6ts could not point 'point to Wikipedia or any similar source that may appear in the future to escape consequences of errors.'" in that article it also showed how misinformation posted on Wikipedia can spread quickly.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: There are several factors that relate to misinformation posted on Wikipedia and how quickly it can spiral out of control. In its earlier days, Wikipedia had to deal with issues such as "vandalism and the lack of a fixed formula for determining what should and should not be included in an encyclopedia unconstrained by physical limits" (Source 2). This made it easy for hackers to feed people the wrong facts, and to instead write about subjects that are completely bizzare. The lack of hard facts can also mislead those who wish to know the real answers. When student Shane Fitzgerald of Dublin University posted a phony quote on the page of French composer Maurice Jarre, an obituarist used that quote when writing about Jarre (Source 4). Fitzgerald's experiment, in this case, was a success, showing how journalists rely on Wikipedia and do not take the time to review their sources. These are a few of the several ways Wikipedia presents minsinformation.

He said how he was "testing how our globalized, increasingly Internet-dependent media was upholding accuracy and accountability in an age of instant news." And with fooling nearly the entire world, his point was pretty much proven. Many people access Wikipedia for either the same or various reasons, but nevertheless, it is a source that most people rely on, despite whether the information is true or false. According to Source #3, Wikipedia articles are "Created by users, not traditional 'experts'", so anyone could edit or write articles and put down false information, and people would read it and believe it anyways. And with many people using Wikipedia to search up the same, popular thing, false information could easily spread.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Often when rushing to cram for an exam, students flip to the first source they can find to get information. Most commonly that source is wikipedia, being one of the first results when typing something into google. In source #5, a teacher found that "The obscure, though incorrect, information was from wikipedia, the collaborative online encyclopedia, and the students had picked it up cramming for his exam." Writers for wikipedia "shouldn't use information they find if it can't be traced back to a reliable primary source." Misinformation is spread throughout this site due to one, the overall entry of the misinformation, and two, people reusing that information on a new entry or on another site.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Wikipedia has misinformation because the entries are created by its users, not professionals. Anyone can go on Wikipedia and post whatever they like. Many people have posted false information on Wikipedia just to see if the world would recognize the false information. Shane Fitzgerald was the first person to come out and say that he posted something false on Wikipedia. His explantion said that, "he was testing how our globalized, increasingly Internet-dependent media was upholding accuracy and accountability in an age of instant news" (Source #4). Wikipedia is also supposed to have users specifically for editing the false information posted on the website. It is hard to edit all the posts quickly before the false information is already spread. Source #2 tells us that, "as the project grew, vandalization and dilution of the encyclopedia's content became more difficult to address."

data_answer: The power of Wikipedia comes at a price and its audience and users may pay a large one. The amount of information found on Wikipedia is large, yet its reliability and validity may not be as accurate as one thinks. The information which Wikipedia presents is produced by " ordinary users instead of experts (source 3)." The database for information comes from placing one's faith in the accuracy and knowledge of another person who may not know all there is to know when it relates to certain article posted on Wikipedia. Thus as more users use Wikipedia and may help another person, the spread of false information mutiplies as more people rely on Wikipedia. The social experiment to measure the rates of globalization by Dublin's Shane Fitzgerald took " less than three minutes ot fabricate a false quote (source 4)" which spread across the globe triggered the fear of the spread of false information. As the experiment revealed that the growth of internet usage leads to faster communication between computer systems, one can only imagine that the "quick quote" took less than twenty-four hours to be distributed across the globe. This fast spread of false information is born form unreliable sources which is then amplified by the enhancement of fast internet. Wikipedia and its datbase of knowledge, in an instant, can spread faulty information in minutes and as more people use it the rate only quickens, raising the price of using Wikipedia.

In source # 4, an Irish student named Fitzgerald posted a fake quote online of Maurice Jarre. This quote had took him less than 15 minutes to fabricate and place. Administrators quickly removed the quote's lack of attribution but was not fast enough as some journalists already cut and pasted it first (Source #4). Through these examples, wikipedia can not be trusted as posts from users may be false and made just for attention.

data_answer: Wikipedia is an easily accessible website that all users have access to and can edit publicly or use information from. As an "experiment" to see how fast misinformation can be posted, this Irish student had posted a poetic but phony quote on Wikipedia, and it was swallowed by society. Wikipedia is also shown as a source for misinformation produced by an article from The Taipei Times by Noam Cohen, where students were using misinformation that they had picked up from Wikipedia on a test and getting it wrong. This can easily happen because as students, we are faced with many tests throughout our school years and in order to study for this we turn to the Internet. The Internet provides an easy to access style that many students eagerly need and Wikipedia is a site that provides all that for students like these. Even though the adminstrators of the page deleted the quote, some journalists were too quick and used cut and paste. A month later he came out saying that it was his quote and was just a fraud. He then said "It would have become another example where, once anything is printed enought times in the media without challenge, it becomes a fact." This means that people can get away with posting fake information on wikipedia and can simply fool others. It can easily trick researchers if they have not seen any other information other than the writings in wikipedia. In source number two it states "with 2.92 mistakes per article for Britannica and 3.86 for Wikipedia no one argues that Wikipedia's content is flawless."

data_answer: Misinformation can spread easily on Wikipedia because various people have access causing some inaccurate information to be inputed. Source #4, published by The Seattle TImes, is about a hoax of a fake quote uploaded. Wikipedia allows anyone to use it, leading to many people believing it since so many people edit different articles all the time. An Irish student made up a quote, then uploaded it to Wikipedia which caused an uproar by numerous people reviewing that said article. "The sociology major's made-up quote... flew straight on to dozens of U.S. blogs and newspaper Web sites in Britain, Austrailia and India." Since many people look at Wikipedia, most information people see on it believe it without going through much effort to see if the actual information is legitimate. The last source, Source #5 is about the inaccuracy of Wikipedia which is being used by numerous students around the world. The downside that people found was that the students, praised for researching, were however finding inaccurate research which didn't benefit their actual knowledge. "... about a year ago that students were citing Wikipedia as a source in their papers. When confronted, many would say that their high school teachers had allowed the practice. But the errors on the test last semester were the last straw." Since so many people have access to the internet, the ability to find the wrong information is endless, the main site searched being Wikipedia. Numerous teachers admit that Wikipedia is inaccurate but still find Wikipedia semi-useful. "'I guess I am not terribly impressed by anyone citing an encyclopedia as a reference point, but I am not against using it as a starting point." Even teachers find that Wikipedia can help students, but want to make the students understand that Wikipedia shouldn't be their primary source or even their only sourcce. Wikipedia in the long run is controversial for many people to how useful it is. But the main issue is how fast the misinformation would spread to others, which in the long run woud decieve people and lead them to continously remember incorrect information.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: The main reason that misinformation posted on Wikipedia can spread quickly is that many people who use the website do not verify that the information found on Wikipedia is true. This idea can be clearly seen in Article #4, "Irish Student Hoaxes World's Media with Fake Quote", in which Dublin university student Shane Fitzgerald posted a fake quote on Wikipedia that was used by many media outlets despite being removed from Wikipedia within a few hours. Once the quote was revealed to be a hoax, the reader's editor at The Guardian, one of the newespapers that posted the fake quote, stated, "The moral of this story is not that journalists should avoid Wikipedia, but that they shouldn't use information they find there if it can't be traced back to a reliable primary source." Another example of lack of outside fact checking causing misinformation from Wikipedia to spread can be seen in Article #5, "Wikipedia on an Academic Hit List". This article describes a case when a number of students in a Japanese history class at Middlebury College used the same false argument in their essay, stemming from an incorrect fact found on Wikipedia. This led to the college professor banning the citing of Wikipedia as a source, stating that it should only be used a first step to finding reliable sources. Wikipedia co-founder Jimmy Wales agreed with this policy, stating, "They are recommending exactly what we suggested-students shouldn't be citing encyclopedias." This article also proves that Wikipedia can be a useful tool, but without fact-checking it with outside information, incorrect information can spread quickly.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: In source #4, Pogatchnik explains the story of a student named Fitzgerald posting a phony quote on a composers page after the composers death. Fitzgerald was testing if media would be able to notice if this is a credible source or if they would remove it for being a fraud. The media however, through its hunger to spread what it can, 'cut and paste' the quote without checking its source. Although Wikipedia removed the quote, the media never noticed the fraud until Fitzgerald came out and explained what had happened. Supporting this, Pogatchnik states, "I am 100-percent convinced that if i hadn't come forward, that quote would have gone down in history as something Maurice Jarre said, instead of something i made up. It would have become another example where, once anything is printed enough times in the media without challenge. it becomes a fact." This quote is an example on how the misinformation that was posted on Wikipedia spread and that was because of media. Another source would be source #5, written by Noam Cohen on a japanese history class professor noticing that exams that were turned in held multiple and repeated errors. The professor, Neil Waters, concludes that,"The obscure, though incorrect, information was from Wikipedia, the collaborative online encyclopedia, and the students had picked it up cramming for his exam." However, this was not a good thing. The wikipedia source gave away different information, usually incorrect, and he noticed this in the exam. Cohen writes that, "But the errors on the test last semester were the last straw," and furthermore explains Waters' determination to stop wikipidea from being a cited source on papers or exams becuase of the misinformation.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Wikipedia can hold and spread misinformation due to the way that it was created and is currently run. To protect against vandalisma and misinformation being added to the page Wikipedia has "a volunteer army of editors" who make sure that nothing incorrect gets added (Source #2). However, this volunteer army may take some time to catch every mistake in all 1 million or more articles. There is a log created, but oftentimes the mistakes aren't caught quick enough. In the incident described in Source #4, the encyclopedia caught and removed the fake quote, "but not quickly enough to keep some journalists from cutting and pasting it first" (Source #4). Since people are one Wikipedia all the time, any misinformation not caught immediately can be snagged by someone and used as correct if not found elsewhere.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Although wikipedia can be credible most of the time, there are moments where misinformation can be posted. Even though these mishaps are usually fixed within minutes or hours it can sometimes have a big affect. Such as Shane Fitzgerald posting a fake poetic quote on the page of Maurice Jarre hours after the french composers death. Where many Journalists and Blogs began to put in thier obituraries. Fitzgerlad said " I am 100 percent convinced that if I hadn't come foward, that quote would have gone down in history as something Maurice Jarre said instead of something I made up." "It would have become another example where, once anything is printed enough time in the media without challenge, it becomes fact." - "Irish Student Hoaxes World's Media With Fake Quote" by The Seattle Times. A study shown by Nature found "that Wikipedia's science entiries came close to matching the Encyclopedia Britannica's in terms of accuracy-with 2.92 mistakes per article for Britannica and 3.86 for Wikipedia- no one argues that Wikipedias content is flawless." This also shows that although that wikipedia can be a credible source most of the time, it is not always right.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Misinformation posted on Wikipedia can spread rapidly. Just take for example, Shane Fitzgerald, for when he posted a poetic but phony quote on Wikipedia about a recently dead composer, it "flew straight on to dozens of U.S. blogs and newspaper Web sites in Britain, Australia, and India." (Source 4). Journalists and other individuals that thrive to have the story first or get their article out on time rush to internet sources to fufill that request. Even Wales said "If they put out a statement not to read Wikipedia at all, I would be laughing. They might as well say don't listen to rock 'n' roll either. (Source 5). With students and adults frequently using Wikipedia for their studies and other purposes, the misinformation posted can spread quickly.

Immeditaley this fake quote had been put into circulation by the media, although Wikipedia caught on that it was false, and pulled it down. This shows why misinformation posted on Wikipedia can spread quickly because it shows how social media, has a drive to get information on a hot topic, as quickly as possible. And since Wikipedia is the first source seen usually on a webpage, it shows how quickly it can spread becasue it will be the first place people will go to get information on a topic. data_answer: With any website, misinformation can spread very quickly. However, invalid information on Wikipeida spreads faster than anything. label: TRAINING
data_answer: In the beggining, Wikipedia was dealing with a lot of different problems, one of them being vandalism. Source # 2 explains just why this what happening and how Wikipedia has worked to solve this problem. "...Amoung them were vandalism and the lack of a fixed formula for determining what should and shouldn't be included in an encyclopedia unconstrained by physical limitations. The emerging community included a volunteer army of editors, who helped to keep the content aligned with Wikipedia's rules..." The poor guidelines set by Wikipedia when it first came out was a big reason as to why the sources and information on the website were invalid. This has since been changed. Source # 4 gave a good example of just how fast false information can spread because of Wikipedia by telling the story of a boy named Shane Fitzgerald who made up a quote who he claimed was said by Maurice Jarre hours after the French composer's death. This quote made its way to dozens of blogs and newspaper Web sites in the U.S., Britain, Australia, and India. Fitzgerald said, "The used fabricated material even though administrators at the free online encyclopedia quickly caught the quote's lack of attribution and removed it, but not quickly enough to keep some journalists from cutting and pasting it first." Months had gone on and yet nobody noticed the false information untl Fitzgerald had told several media outlets. Fitzgerald concluded by stating, "I am 100-percent convinced that if I hadn't come forward, that quote would have gone down in history as something Maurice Jarre said, instead of something I made up. It would have become another example where, once anything is printed enough times in the media without challenge, it becomes fact."

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Misinformation posted on Wikipedia can spread quickly. This likely occurs because the media of today's world doesn't always uphold accuracy, especially when we live in a world that feeds off of instant news. In source #4, an article titled 'Irish student hoaxes world's media with fake quote' written by Shawn Pogatchnik, Pogatchnik explains how society's desire for instant news allows many to be gullible and believe anything on the internet. In the article, Pogatchnik writes, "When Dublin university student Shane Fitzgerald posted a poetic but phony quote on Wikipedia, he said he was testing how our globalized, increasingly Internet-dependent media was upholding accuracy and accountability in an age of instant news. His report card: Wikipedia passed. Journalism flunked." Pogatchnik goes on to add..."The sociology major's made up quote flew straight on to dozens of U.S. blogs and newspaper Web sites in Britain, Austrailia and India." Here, the author of source #4 demonstrates how rapidly, and how far away, false information can spread. Misinformation posted on Wikipedia can also spread quickly due to the fact that it has a very wide audience. Source #5, titled 'Wikipedia on an academic hit list' written by Noam Cohen states that, "Indeed, the English-language version of the Web site had an estimated 38 million users in the US in December, and can be hard to avoid while on the Internet." Because so many people have access to and are able to see false information on Wikipedia, this information spreads at a much higher rate.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Wikipedia is known to be reliable but it is also known to provide other with misinformation. In "Irish student hoaxes world's media with fake quote" (source #4), the author Shawn Pogatchnik tells a story of a Dublin university student posted a fake quote on wikipedia. Shawn was testing how quick Wikipedia was to find the inaccuracy in this quote. Misinformation can spread quickly on wikipedia because as soon as it is online people are quick to copy and paste this information and there are thousands of articles administrators have to check. By the time an administrator checked the article it would be late and they might not even have found the mistake. Shawn had to email the organization after a month went by without his fake quote being changed. This is one example of how misinformation posted on Wikipedia can spread quickly. Source #5 also provides an accurate example of how quickly misinformation can spread on Wikipedia. In "Wikipedia on an academic hit list" A professor of Middlebury College found an error in students' papers regarding the Shimabara Rebellion in Japan. He then realized that the source of this error was from Wikipedia. This innacurate information had been on Wikipedia long enough for students to use it in their papers and recieve a bad grade due to the wrong information. These sources support the arguement that misinformation posted on Wikipedia can spread quickly.

data_answer: Misinformation posted on Wikipedia can spread quickly because anyone can edit information on that site. However, according to source #2, A Brief History of Wikipedia, by Dan Fletcher, the article stated that the site's software keeps a log of every modification to every page, and this tracking system helped the company ban high-profile offenders. Wikipedia even IP banned addresses owned by the Church of Scientology because they don't want biast articles and want them to have a neutral point of view. Also, Wikipedia usually has 3.86 mistakes per article compared to 2.92 mistakes by Britannica and because anyone can edit on the site, they may want to change what the article already has. Also according to source #4, Wikipedia's system requires 1,500 volunteer administrators to spot article changes and deletions, which may be hard to do since there are over millions of articles on Wikipedia and anyone can edit the articles with ease from any computer they are on.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: One reason why this may happen is because the media takes information from Wikipedia and publishes it, spreading the word like wildfire. This exact thing happened when a college student by the name of Shane Fitzgerald posted a fake quote on the website. While the gatekeepers of Wikipedia took the quote down, many media outlets had already taken it and published it themselves (Source 3). This also may happen when students in school are researching a topic and use Wikipedia as a source. If they come across faulty information, they may begin to tell their classmates this is true as well, and soon people everywhere have heard about this wrong information. This is what happened at Middlebury College in Vermont when too many students believed everything they read on Wikipedia (Source 5).

The Wikipedia system has about 1,500 volunteer administrators that are trained to spot new additions made on pages. The administrators remove any bogus, fabricated, or biased additions in a relatively fast time. In the situation of source 4, the administrators removed the bogus quote in minutes to an hour but it was still the subject of blogs and websites around the globe.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: It is not unheard of that misinformation posted on Wikipedia can spread quickly. This can be caused both by users not following-up out of desperation and/or blind acceptance. For example, in Neil Waters' Japanese history class at Middlebury College, multiple students in the class used the same "obscure, though incorrect, information" on their exams. Waters was able to trace the information back to Wikipedia and conclude that the students were desperate for quick study materials while cramming (Cohen). In the same light, Source #4 reports on an experiment preformed by an Irish student on how quickly false information on Wikipedia spreads. In response to his experiment's astonishing, alarming results, the student, Shane Fitzgerald, says, "If anything...he expected newspapers to avoid his quote because it had no link to a source-and even might trigger alarms as 'too good to be true.' But many blogs and several newspapers used the quotes at the start or finish of their obituaries" (Pogatchnik). Both these examples are because anyone can edit the information on Wikipedia at any time. While there are notifications that are sent to the Wikipedia staff so they can validate the updates, there are many more updates than staff members. This shows how easily misinformation can spread and how little effect the Wikipedia editing staff has on the public information.

data_answer: It is common knowledge that Wikipedia is an encyclopedia written by the people. Therefore, its likely that some of the information that some people have to provide may be invalid. The first article confirms this by saying that there is a massive need for editors. "The emerging community included a volunteer army of editors, who helped to keep the content aligned with Wikipedia's rules, the first version of which Sanger cerated in 2002. As the project grew, vandilization and dilution of the encyclopedia's content became more difficult to adress. The site's software keeps a log of every modification to every page, and this tracking system has been used to bust some high-profile offenders." (Fletcher). This means that there are enough vandalizers of Wikipedia that some of them even need to be kept on a tight leash. Such an example of such poisonous content would be an Irish student hoazing the world's media with a fake quote (Pogatchnik). This student was specifically attempting to see how information was received and interpreted, valid or not, in an age of instant news. He put words in the mouth of a then recently deceased composer on Wikipedia. Before Wikipedia could take care of the fake quote, journalists and blogs had already copy-pasted it to thee world (Pogatchnik).

data_answer: In Source #4, the false quote that was put onto Wikipedia was quickly taken by the media. Though vague, the speed in which it was seen, retrieved, and published by the media was nonetheless at an exponential rate. First off, it was also pointed out that the quote was rermoved from Wikipedia three times within minutes or hours, but the fact that, if it was indeed a few minutes, the media was able to grasp that quote within that short of a timespan and didn't bother checking out whether it was a fact or not proves that the information on Wikipedia can go viral at any given second, albeit real or fake. Also, Source #2 talks about how large of a page count Wikipedia has; "...more than 13 million articles in 271 different languages" (Fletcher). In addition, it also states that there were "...more than 100 billion pages views..." which also counts for the amount of traffic Wikipedia gets. As a result, what is stated in Source #3, solid key points but vague explainations, can ultimately lead to somewhat correct information, but become misinterpretted by a group of people which eventually takes that information as a fact and continues to spread it until it becomes a large misconception.

In the case of Wikipedia once their information is out there, there is a slim chance they can take it back before it has fallen into the hands of another. As source 1 leads with " 42% of all Americans turn to the popular collavorative encyclopedia for information online..." with almost half of Americans turning to the internet information, whether it be true or false travels quiclkly. In addition to that although sites such as Wikipedia say they monitor false edits they cannot catch them all. In source 4 a student at Dublin Universtiy posted false information on Wikipedia to "test how our globalized increasingly Internet-dependen media was upholding accuracy and accountability in the age of instant news." His false information was not cought by the many systems put in place specifically to do so and he goes on to say that "If I hadn't cme forward, that quote would have gone down in history as something Maurice Jarre said, insted of something I made up...'

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Even though Wikipedia keeps records of every entry and edit to articles, there are still several errors that the editors aren't able to fix. "If anything, Fitzgerald said, he expected newspapers to avoid his quote because it had no link to a source--- and even might trigger alarms as "too good to be true." But many blogs and newspapers used the quote at the start or finish of their obituaries." (Source #4). In source #4, the newspaper describes the story about a student who purposely put false information in a popular Wikipedia article to see if it would be edited or noticed. The information was actually published in newspaper articles about the subject, and the student notified Wikipedia to say it was false. False information can spread quickly because sources are not often evaluated before the content of them is used. In another article, false information was also spread quickly. "The obscure, though incorrect, information was from Wikipedia, the collaborative online encyclopedia, and the students had picked it up cramming for his exam." (Source #5). The fact that a Wikipedia article is the first thing that pops up when someone types in a subject into google is a reason why misinformation can spread so fast. The students mentioned in source 5 weren't trying to use false information, they didn't know any better because Wikipedia is a popular internet site that contained much information on the study subject.

data_answer: One source that shows misinformation can spread quickly is Source #4. In this article, a student by the name of Shane Fitzgerald posted a quote on a Wikipedia page. The page was for the recently, at the time, passed away Maurice Jarre, who had won and Oscar for composing three times. Fitzgerald posted a false quote that he thought of himself. Then several obituarist used the quote in an obituary, without checking to see if Jarre actually said it. This is misinformation that is spreading to anyone who reads the obituary. The obituarist didn't check to see if the information was correct, and now it's spreading. Another source that demonstrates misinformation spreading quickly is source #5. In this source, students use false information from Wikipedia for answers on a test. The information the students got was that "the Jesuits supported the Shimabara Rebellion in 17th-century Japan." This information is incorrect. The professor knew that the correct information they needed was that there were very few Jesuits in Japan. The ones in Japan were in hiding, and they were in "no position to aid a revolution." This misinformation can make students put down incorrect answers on their tests. Many students may use the same article on a test they are taking. So they would also be getting the false information.

data_answer: Wikipedia is relatively an accurate source, but it contains flaws that can be result in the spread of false information. In source 4, the author was talking about Shane Fitzgerald's experiment with Wikipedia. She made quotes and information and saw that many used these false information was used in many blogs and articles. As shown in source 4, a simple falsified information can have rampant effect that can give many places inaccurate informations. The reason for this is shown in source 2. First, the budget for the program is exorbitant. WIkipedia requires around 6 million dollars per year and since Wikipedia refuses to use advertisements, it relies heavily on donations. Despite the large amounts of volunteers in correcting the website, it has a relatively small resource to work with considering it is run by only donations. This sparse resource makes it harder for editors to find mistakes and problems among the million articles that they have. Second reason for the quick spread of misinformation is the amount of users of WIkipedia. In source 3, it shows that more than 10 million users use Wikipedia. Source 5 states that the use of Wikipedia is so prevalent, banning it would be like saying to the whole populace not to listen to rock and roll. Both sources shows that Wikipedia is widely use and thus many people access the articles. If there is a single mistake, millions of users will read that information and take it for a fact not knowing that the information is wrong. With its sparse resource and the number of users, it is easy for a misinformation to spread very quickly.

data_answer: Misinformation on Wikipedia can spread quickly for two reasons. The first is that almost anybody can edit the articles posted on Wikipedia. Dan Fletcher of TIME magazine, said that "as [Wikipedia] grew, vandalization and dilution of the encyclopedia's content became more difficult to address (Source #2)." The second reason why misinformation spreads so quickly on Wikipedia, is that media outlets and journalists are using the information on Wikipedia without double-checking their information. An Irish student named Shane Fitzgerald fabricated a quote from Maurice Jarre and put it on Wikipedia right after Jarre's death. Fitzgerald then found that a number of news outlets were using the fictional quote in thier articles. He claims that know one would've found out if he never notified anyone about it (Source #4).

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Misinformation on wikipedia can spread quickly because a lot of journalists, immediately get information mostly from the internet without even checking the original source. Irish student Shane Fitzgerald posted a fake quote on wikipedia for a French composer named Maurice Jarre that passed away recently, and many journalists used the same made up quote in many U.S blogs and newspaper articles, before wikipedia had the chance to even remove it. (Source 4.) This show how fast wrong information can get across. Another instance was a few students at Middlebury college,Vermont in a history class. A lot of them were using wikipedia as a resource, and they incorrectly responded on their exams that the "Jesuits supported the Smabara Rebellion." The professor immediately noticed that there was something wrong with that information and found out the students had been using incorrect information from wikipedia. (Source 5.) A big portion of that history class using wikipedia was reading the same wrong information.

It turned out that many of the students had used Wikipedia when they where studing and had all read the same misimformation. Neil decided that it was time to put a foot down. He would no longer let students site Wikipedia on papers or use it, and sites like it, as an escape for errors. The co-founder of Wikipedia said that he didn't think it was a negative thing. He said that students shouldn't site Wikipedia or sites like it and to double check their information. (Source #5)

After a month the student sent e-mails to media outlets explainig what had happened. Only one publication, The Guardian has been the only publication to apoligize. (Pogatchnik) Something similar happened at Middlebury College. When about 12 students in Neil Waters' Japanese history class answered on a test that the Jesuits had supported the Shimabara Rebellion in the 17th century in Japan, the proffesor knew that something had to be wrong. The problem was that the students had used information from Wikipedia, and this information was wrong.Right after this, Wikipedia was banned to be used as a source at the colege.(Cohen) Pogatchnik, Shawn. " Irish Student Hoaxes World's Media With Fake Quote" Cohen, Noam "Wikipedia on an Academic Hit List"

data_answer: Wikipedia is a publicly edited vault of knowledge, and that vault is sometimes wrong. Because people are more trusting of the website, it can lead to false information being published. A student at Dublin univeristity purposley posted a false quote from Maurice Jarre, who had recently died. In a matter of hours the quote was plastered all over news articles and obituaries. It was not however, on Wikipedia, soon after the quote was posted administrators removed the quote for lack of authenticity. Jornalists however continued to use the quote.(4) While this spreading of false information was mainly the result of inattentive journalists and not Wikipedia, sometimes Wikipedia is to blame. Many students, especially in college and highschool use Wikipedia as a source for cramming before a test, and this can sometimes get them in a hard place. More then six students at Middlebury College had put false information on a history test, information they had found on Wikipedia(5). While Wikipedia is a great source of information, people are forgetting that it's not written by experts. It's a great place to find information, but the information should be found somewhere else also.

data_answer: Wikipedia is a vast archive of information but not everything is completely correct. The misinformation in Wikipedia can spread quickly due to the number of users that trust it. A study done by an Irish student by the name of Shane Fitzgerald showed that a number of news outlets use wikipedia for information. His study was simple, he put a fake quote in a Wikipedia page and waited to watch it spread. The quote spread rapidly throughout the world and many news organizations were shamed to be found so gullible (4). Another incedent of misinformation happened in a history class located at Middlebury College in Vermont. A professor noticed a mistake that was being commonly made on a test. Further inquiry into it showed that his students had used Wikipedia to find information but they had not checked the accuracy of the article. A volenteer author for Wikipedia had made a small mistake that showed just how unreliable Wikipedia could be if it were totally depended on. This led to the college not accepting Wikipedia as a valid source for a citation (5).

data_answer: According to source 4, misinformation can spread quickly on Wikipedia due to the sites popularity with journalists to obtain information. Another way Wikipedia's misinformation can spread quickly is by it's popularity with students. According to a teacher though, studetns were turning in reports with false information on them with Wikipedia listed as a source. label: TRAINING
data_answer: Misinformation posted on Wikipedia can spread quickly because users are typically in a rush to find answers or information. For example, in his article, "Irish student hoaxes world's media with fake quote," Shawn Pogatchnik discusses how as and experiment, a student was able to spread false information about a deceased composer by posting it on Wikipedia soon after the composer's death. The experiment was designed to test the student's hypothesis that, "...under pressure to produce news instantly, media outlets were increasingly relying on Internet sources--none more ubiquitous than the publicly edited Wikipedia." This proved to be true as the false information was published by hasty journalists in newspapers and blogs. Another example of this can be found in, "Wikipedia on an academic hit list," by Noam Cohen. Cohen describes how students in a hurry to find information to study for their exam led them to trusting false information on Wikipedia. he says, "The obscure, though incorrect, information was from Wikipedia, the collaborative online encyclopedia, and teh students had picked it up cramming for his exam." Because the students were in such a rush to study, they trusted false information.

Though a tast force of 100's is assigned to correcting and deleting biased, false information, a few mistakes can slip by. As exampled in "Wikipedia on an academic hit list", a college class was able to prove a mistake in the writings of an article about the Shimabara Rebellion. Though the students knew better, a learning, oblivious user would have no idea about the misinformation. This is a faulty detail to Wikipedia and user-discretion must then be applied heavily. Along with misinformation that can easily be proved wrong, often details,quotes and other easy mishandeled information can be put up by the writers of Wikipedia. Shane Fitzgerald proved this when he made up a quote on a newly desist composer (source 4). Though Wikipedia soon removed the information, there was enough time for people to read it and believe its invalidty. This creates a whole different problem because a twist in information can be left forever and become a part of history even if it was completely false to begin with. The fact that in both situations the spread of misinformation was very fast or not even caught is a major problem with Wikipedia and its use.

In this case, the first thing someone finds on whatever they may be looking up is most likely what they are going to believe. In Source #4 a student from Dublin University posted a fake quote to a French composer's Wikipedia page only hours after his death. This fake quote had been used on dozens of U.S. blogs and newspaper websites in Britain, Australia, and India. Without the editors of these even thinking, they quickly used this fake quote in the obituaries they had written. Soon they had found out that this quote had not been said by Jarre himself but in fact made up by a student just to test how media would handle it. In Source #2 it talks about how Wikipedia's writing is clunky or prome to bias and that the authors focus on pet projects. The site is used more for interesting things rather than history or things that may actually matter and not just hobbies. So with millions of people adding their input, it may not always be correct. label: TRAINING
data_answer: Wikipedia has become a go-to source of information for students writing a research paper to journalists and columnists creating a news article. When looking into the influence of the internet on media reports, Irish student Shane Fitzgerald found "a golden opportunity" to expose the too-easily fooled media reporters for their lack of adequate research (4). The death of a famous composer led the student to enter a made-up quote onto the composer's biographical Wikipedia article (4). The flood of media flocking to online sources to quickly come up with an article on the compser's death was too easily tricked by the insertion of false information, and they quickly proceeded to report the quote as one of the late composer's very own (4). Misinformation stemming from a rush to make the day's paper is not the only source of false reporting. Students in a Japenese history college course reported on an event in history that never actually occurred (5). The late cram sessions that the students consulted Wikipedia in resulted in students learning false information (5). This occurs due to the students waiting until the last minute to prepare and rushing to learn information that should be verified with other information.

In Source #5, Wikipedia on an academic hit list by Noam Cohen, he tells us how students rely on Wikipedia for information, although the information may be false. Once one student finds the answer to their question on Wikipedia, other students will. For example the students in Neil Waters Japanese history class at Middlebury College, Vermont all put on their exams that the Jesuits supported the Shimabara Rebellion in the 17th-century when in fact they did not, but found their answer on Wikipedia, which was wrong.

The quote was tailor-made for obituaries, and journalists jumped at the opportunity to use such a perfect line. The quote was widely claimed as being something Jarre actually said, and despite the facts that there was no primary source to back it up, and that administrators caught and removed the quote immediately, the damage had been done. The student called major news instutions and explained that the quote was a fake. Source #4 shows that certain people might use Wikipedia as a cop-out; it is a slough of easily available information that they do not have to put any real work in to access. Many use Wikipedia for this reason. Source #5 is a news story about a class of students enrolled in a Japanese history class at Middlebury College in Vermont. It explains a situation in which a number of students gave incorrect information on a test after using information obtained on Wikipedia to study. The frequency of this mistake was noticed, and when asked about why they used Wikipedia as a reliable source, the students stated that their high-school teachers had allowed it. This shows that Wikipedia is being widely accepted as a source that is accurate, adn those who use Wikipedia take the information presented there as the truth.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Misinformation spreads quickly no matter what situation one is in, but the internet has made it much easier and faster. Wikipedia has had a lot of criticism for this rapid spreading of false information. This could happen for a number of reasons. "Irish student hoaxes world's media with fake quote" explains how Wikipedia removed this false information, "but not quickly enough to keep some journalists from cutting and pasting it first." Because people didn't double-check information, a fake quote spread very quickly to other types of journalism. This wasn't necessarily Wikipedia's fault though, considering that they removed the information; the reason it was spread was due to journalists' lack of research. "Wikipedia, Past and Present" also considers reasons for quickly spreading information. Between 2007 and 2010, Wikipedia users increased from 25% to 42%. So, if the number of people using and spreading information from Wikipedia is increasing, the misinformation increases as well.

label: VALIDATION
data_answer: Misinformation is sometimes posted on Wikipedia and can spread rapidly. In Source #4, a student at Dublin University, Shane Fitzgerald, posted a fake quote in the Wikipedia article of the recently deceased composer, Maurice Jarre. Many different media outlets used the quote in their stories that reached all across the world. Fitzgerald did this to show how false information can be spread and printed a million times and it will eventually be seen as the truth. He proved his point when even The Guardian, a famous British newspaper, ran the quote in their obituary. Professors at Middlebury College in Vermont have noticed that students often cite Wikipedia as a source in their papers. However, the student's in Neil Water's Japanese history class were fed wrong information which led them to get bad results on their exams. The college has now banned the students from citing Wikipedia as a source for information (Source #5).

On exams at Middlebury College in a Japanese history class, half a dozen students said that the Jesuits supported the Shimabara Rebellion in 17th century Japan. The only student to discover these falsities was Neil Waters. (source 5)

label: VALIDATION
data_answer: Misinformation on Wikipedia can happen, as the website's articles can be edited at any time. In Source 5, Wikipedia articles were unreliable for students studying for a test a night before, as they were studying incorrect infomation on their subject. This show how misinformation can result in negative experiences by the user. In Source 4, Wikipedia spokesman, Jay Walsh stated that "We always tell people: If you see that quote on Wikipedia, find it somewhere else too." This illustrates that lack of reliability for a quote on Wikipedia is. Misinformation can be seen through lack of clarity in an article and the ability for any person to edit any article.

label: VALIDATION
data_answer: Misinformation on WIkipedia spreads easily because of how trusted Wikipedia has become and how corrosive information could be quickly trusted without accurate citations. In source #4, A student from Dublin University fabricated a quote "by" composer Maurice Jarre, "A full month went by and nobody noticed the editoral fraud. So Fitzgerald told several media outlets in an e-mail and the corrections began." This information went undetected because of Fitzgerald claimed that "[Media outlets] were under pressure to produce news instantly". So why did this misinformation spread? One idea is that the writers had only glosed over the cite-less quote. The quote itself neatly fit into the thoughts of a composer; that he "'there will be a final waltz his head only he could hear.'" This quote seemed so likely and so real that pressured editors decisively decided to publish it. The quote was shocking enough to attract attention, while still maintaining a guise of truth. So, it was accepted as "truth". In source #2, Wikipedia at one point in time had "[Wikipedia] reached 3 million entires... more than 10 million users contributed to that milestone..." Unfortunately, The shear amount of users both helps and hurts accuracy of the articles on the website. Some articles with questionable material have a banner that states it needs more sources, along with a "citation needed" box after some material that is questionable. However, some of these notices are old, and like in the previous example, can go unnoticed. Information that is more subjective is often the problem; how can we decide if a country is overall in bad shape or how terrible Huricane Katrina is? Also, certain data that requires strenous work, like populations of people in a certain area, can change very quickly without notice. Since certain countries cannot take Census or take it every few years, it makes it that much harder to have good, valid, and up-to-date data that isn't subject to question.

Bad information spreads because when the information shows up on the internet, people don't double-check with other resources.
