data_answer: In this day and age, the advancement of technology has created a world where siblings from across the globe are able to contact each other in a matter of seconds via the Internet. In relation to the capability of contacting other individuals from anywhere across the world, the Internet has given society a way to spread news like Southern Californian wild fire. Even a single spark that lasts a few seconds can ignite an enraging flame. Similar to the relationship between a spark and a fire, misinformation on Wikipedia can spread in seconds thanks to modern day technology. However, the ones guilty for this spread of information are the users, not the source itself. For instance, journalists are extremely "eager for a quick, pithy quote" when they are trying to meet their deadlines on articles, as stated in Source 4. In their rush to finish their assignments and publish news before their competitors, journalists overlook the quality of their work. The institution of Wikipedia isn't to blame. The spokesman himself even stated that "if you see that quote on Wikipedia, find it somewhere else too." This spreading of misinformation occurs because of a lack of professional ability from the users.

label: VALIDATION
data_answer: Misinformation posted on Wikiipedia can spread quickly due to journalists desperately seeking something to add to an article, or maybe something to write about. Source 4 states that it is not that the inaccurate information is corrected, but, "It was journalists eager for a quick, pithy quote that was the problem" (source 4). The journalists got hold of a false quote posted on the Wikipedia page about French composer Maurice Jarre right after his death, even though it was eventually taken down. Once something is made public though, it will spread around the globe quickly, making it too late for editors to stop the misinformation from spreading. When leaked by the first journalists who saw it, they decided to include it in his or her obituary of the composer, but the quote also found it way onto other websites online. Furthermore, when students at Middlebury College, Vermont were cramming for an exam they looked on the internet for answers. The professor figured out that, "The obscure, though incorrect, information was from Wikipedia...and the students had picked it up cramming for his exam" (source 5). The students were a large group and used Wikipedia to study causing the false infromation to be spread quickly among the tudying students students. In both examples, the information was spread quickly due to the fact that people were in a rush to gain knowledge or information that was inaccurate before it could be taken down by those that take out information that is wrong.

label: VALIDATION
data_answer: Source 4 describes a story of a sociology major who did an experiment by making up a quote, which he claimed came from the famous Oscar-winning actor Maurice Jarre. Though the "1,500 volunteer 'administrators' and the wider public to spot bogus additions did its job, removing the quote three times within minutes or hours" (4), it was not removed "quickly enough to keep some journalists from cutting and pastint it first" (4). Consequently, the misinformation went viral, spreading extremely quickly all over the internet. It was not until Shane Fitzgerald reported to the media that the public realized the quote was phony. In another mishappening, "half a dozen students... asserted that the Jesuits supported the Shimabara Rebellion in 17th-century Japan" (5). According to Professor Neil Waters, this information was wrong as "the Jesuits were in 'no position to aid a revolution'" (5). In both these cases, it was likely that students and journalists simply believed that the information was accurate because it was posted online. This is similar to Milgram's experiment where people were told to give "learners" shocks for incorrrect answers to questions. The shocks were not actually real, but the participants did not know this. Even when the shocks became dangerously high, almost all the participants followed through simply because an authoritative looking man in a lab coat asked them to do so. The conclusion of this experiment was that people tend to trust authoritative or official-looking figures. In this case, the website Wikipedia looked official, consequently making people believe that it is always accurate.

data_answer: Although Wikipedia is a very commonly used site for getting information, it doesn't always supply us with the information we need, rather the incorrect information, which can easily spread among thousands, even millions of people over a short time span. In source 4, a student by the name of Shane Fitzgerald posted a phony quote onto an article for Maurice Jarre, a French composer. Shane was testing to see how accuracy and accountability fell into play in this as he puts it, "internet-dependent media". Shortly after he posts this inaccurate quote, dozens of U.S. blogs and newspaper wbsites in Britain, Australia, and India post this information, without knowing of it's false intent. This information spreads quickly as people don't pay attention to quality as much as they should now adays, they just look for information. These blogs and sites didn't look for a second source for this information, and simply believed that this information was accurate, and posted news about it wihtout thought to it. In source 5, students use Wikipedia to recieve information for an exam. label: VALIDATION
data_answer: Wikipedia has become so vastly popular that many will use it to find information immediately, as the media did to find quotations for various obituaries for singer Maurice Jarre. "Even though administrators...quickly caught the quote's lack of attribution and removed it" (Source 4), it was much too late to stop information-hungry journalists from preying on the Wikipedia article, however inaccurate. The problem is that Wikipedia articles are so widely accessible and available: even with the censoring and cross-checking that keeps the information accurate, it is hard to stop all of the users that get on to an article before such misinformation is removed. The Internet is available everywhere: a million people can read an article before one editor, even if that editor reads this article ten minutes after its conception. And by then it is far too late for the million people that have been misinformed and haven't bothered to check up on their accuracy. Additionally, the sheer number of articles, "13 million...in 271 different languages" (Source 2), prevent any number of editors from truly being able to validate every piece of information included on such a vast online encyclopedia. "Obscure...incorrect information" (Source 5) is not an uncommon thing: it simply goes unnoticed in the gigantic arena of the collection. But when, say, a college history class has a big test they need to cram for, these tiny obscure details spread to a point that proves unacceptable. The problem with Wikipedia is not necessarilly a large quantity of inaccuracies, but the potential effects that those inaccuracies may have.

The study done by the Irish college student shows that when a topic is trending, any information found is used widely. Following the death of a famous musician, many people were looking him up to find out more about this late man. The student took the opportunity to post a page about him on Wikipedia, inserting a false quote. Within days, even hours, the quote spread quickly and was seen in newpapers and articles. Wikipedia was used as a popular source of reference, so the information spread rapidly.

label: VALIDATION
data_answer: Wikipedia is a privately run buisness that has an array of editors and publishers constantly revising and editing the site to keep inaccurate information from being added to the site. However, since it can be added to by the general public, the editors are kept busy keeping Wikipedia accurate. A 22 year old student at Dublin University decided to put Wikipedia editors and Newspaper journalists to the test by putting a phony quote of a recently deceased composer on Wikipedia. [1] Even though the Wikipedia editors removed it quickly, within a few hours, the quote showed up in several newspapers all over, including Britian's The Guardian. This happened because the journalists stumbled upon the quote without checking it's accuracy with other sources. Students in a Japanese History class at Middlebury College also took information from Wikipedia without checking other sources while studying for a test. The information they cited was wrong, as their professor was able to correct them. [2] This also happened because the students did not check for other sources to say the same thing. This can happen on any site, but Wikipedia has a notorious reputation for inacurate information. [1] Source #4 Irish Student Hoaxes World's Media With Fake Quote by Shawn Pogatchnik from The Seattle Times. [2] Source #5 Wikipedia on an Acedemic Hit List by Noam Cohen from The Taipei Times.

label: VALIDATION
data_answer: The article "Irish Student Hoaxes World's Media With Fake Quote" written by Shawn Pogatchnik shows the weakness not of Wikipedia itself but of the people who use it. This article tells the story of a student who wanted to see how easily people would pick up on a fake bit of information that was posted on Wikipedia that was made to sound real; his test of Wikipedia and the world showed that Wikipedia caught the error much faster than the rest of the world and that the media of the world used the quote without checking any background primary sources for affirmation of the legitimacy of the quote. The key with Wikipedia is to always check a primary source along with it. In "Wikipedia on an Academic Hit List" by Noam Cohen it is said that university proffessors do not oppose the use of Wikipedia, or any other encyclopedia for that matter, as a starting point for researching a topic, but they do oppose citing Wikipedia as a source. Once again the key with Wikipedia is that is cannot be used as a source but as a step in the direction of finding the source that you is needed.

label: VALIDATION
data_answer: Misinformation on Wikipedia can spread very quickly and it is demonstrated in a few of the articles. In source #4 it talks about a Dublin university student named Shane Fitzgerald that was doing a sociology experiment to see how fast false information on the site Wikipedia could spread. There was a Wikipedia page on the French composer Maurice Jarre. Jarre had died just hours before and Shane saw his chance to do his experiment, so he posted a quote on the page that was supposedly said by the composer but was not. And sure enough within a couple of hours of that quote being on the page, journalists from all over Europe had swooped in and copied it to put in their obituaries on the deceased composer. To Fitzgerald's surprise his experiment had worked profoundly more than he had imagined. The team at Wikipedia that edits the site and checks the reliability of the entries, found the quote and erased it as soon as they found it, but some journalists had already picked up the information. Fitzgerald did release a statement saying that he was the one who posted the quote and was doing it for research purposes. His experiment shows that anything that is put on the internet will be used by people, and that it can spread like wild fire. People that use Wikipedia rarely check the validity of the information that they are receiving and just assume that whoever did post the article was being truthful about it, some people even believe that others can not just edit Wikipedia as they please. This goes to show that whoever does use a site like Wikipedia should check how valid the information that they retained is before they start spreading it to others. Also information on Wikipedia, whether true or false, may spread very quickly do to the number of users that are on the site. In source #1 it shows a graph on the percentage of adults in America that use the internet compared to the percentage of those that use Wikipedia. By 2010 79% of adults in America used the internet, and 42% of them used Wikipedia as a source. With this bulk of people using the site it's no wonder that information on topics can spread so quickly whether it is valid or not. No matter what it is the more people that see it the more likely it is that it is going to be spread, and eventually some people will even start to believe it is true if they have heard it from enough people. Misinformation on Wikipedia does spread extremely fast and those that use the site should double check the information before using it in articles or just retelling it to their friends.

The Jesuits were in "no position to aid a revolution," he said; the few of them in Japan were in hiding"(Source 5). label: VALIDATION
data_answer: Wikipedia is known to be a website that you should not use because it is not written by experts but only by volunteers. When an Oscar winning composer died, of course Wikipedia was blowing up with views of people who wanted to know who he was and what he had done in his lifetime. So as an experiment Shane Fitzgerald decided to put a false quote on the late composer's Wikipedia page to see how fast it would travel around the world. His plan worked and anyone who saw the page believed that the quote was actually said by the Oscar winner (Source #4). Therefore anyone could put anything on Wikipedia and it could be perceived as true. In another source, it was said that college students were using Wikipedia and they were all getting the same fact wrong on a paper they had to write for class (Source #5). Middlebury College debated on whether they should even allow students to use Wikipedia as a source.

label: VALIDATION
data_answer: Misinformation on Wikipedia can spread like wildfire. In Ireland, a student posted a seemingly legitimate quote to Wikipedia (Source #4). People used this quote from Wikipedia in the supposed author's obituary all around the world. This shows how quickly false information can spread. In Vermont, students in a Japanese history class stated, on an exam, that the Jesuits supported the Shimabara Rebellion in Japan (Source #5). In fact, the truth was the opposite. After researching this peculiar statement, Neil Waters found that the students got this information from Wikipedia. Waters made huge steps to mark Wikipedia off the "credible source" list, and the students would no longer be able to use it in their papers or on their exams. According to this evidence, Wikipedia can be credible, but in some cases is not and can cause major issues.

label: VALIDATION
data_answer: The information on Wikipedia is not always reliable. This website was originally supposed to be there to help people learn about different things that others knew more about. There was one stipulation though, it is produced by anyone who wants to put an article on it. Anyone could be a Wikipedia editor or article producer, but the information won't always be safe to use for reports or newspapers. In Source #4 a young college student published a quote on Wikipedia to test how fast the fake quote would get across the Inter-web. He made up a quote and put that Maurice Jarre said it. This was everywhere. Newspapers had his quote in their paper's obituary sections or in memory of him type deals. Another example is in Source #5 a professor told his students that they could no longer use Wikipedia as a source. They were using bad or false information and it needed to stop.

label: VALIDATION
data_answer: Misinformation can spread quicker then we know these days. With the technology we have, it does not take much time for a piece of information to get onto the web. In,"Irish student hoaxes world's media with fake quote", A Dublin university student shows how quickly we trust a piece of information put on the web for public display. Shane Fitzgerald found the opportunity when Maurice Jarre passed away. Fitzgerald posted a quote he made up in Wikipedia, but said Jarre had said it. Within hours of this quote being posted, it was taken down by the administrators, however journalists had already seen and used it. After Fitzgerald allowed about a month to go by he decided he should probably tell media outlets about what had happened so they could make the corrections. Another example of misinformation was presented when Neil Waters' Japanese history class at Middlebury College was preparing for an exam. He noticed that about half a dozen students answered a question with the Jesuits supporting the Shimabara Rebellion. When Waters was noticed that the students had researched and found their answer on Wikipedia, he took it to the history department and they agreed that it could not be cited in papers or exams. This information was taken from Source #5.

label: VALIDATION
data_answer: Wikipedia, in some cases, has been proven somewhat unreliable in the information given out, but it is shocking at how fast the bad information can get out there. One reasoning why this false information might spread so quickly is because of the need for news and information now that happens without double checking sources throughout our society. "The sociology major's made-up quote--wich he added to the Wikipedia page of Maurice Jarre hours after the French composer's death March 28--flew straight on to dozens of U.S. blogs and newspaper Web sites in Britain, Australia and India," said Shawn Pogatchnik in the article "Irish student hoaxes world's media with fake quote," (Pogatchnik.) Another reasoning as to why false information might spread so quickly is just the lazyness of some researchers. "The obscure, though incorrect, information was from Wikipedia, the collaborative online encyclopedia, and the students had picked it up cramming for his exam," said Noam Cohen in his article "Wikipedia on an academic hit list," (Cohen.)

label: VALIDATION
data_answer: Misinformation can be spread quickly due to the current demand for instant news, as opposed to upholding nearly definitive accuracy. Source #4 highlights this point, using Dublin student Shane Fitzgerald as an example. Fitzgerald's phony Wikipedia quote was spread by dozens of news blogs and Web sites who were desperate to report on the death of the supposed quote's speaker. This massive spreading of misinformation may also have something to do with the level of people who actively use Wikipedia. Source #1 contains evidence that illustrates the fact that 42% of all American adults now use Wikipedia as an information source. With a user base of millions upon millions of people, there is more articles and less ability to fact check.
